abeb4c0ac6ffb27ee5fbbc20aca0b2f4 (16:40): ef6f2287bae00ba79475fbf56c2b6fee: what is the point of features that authors won't buy into?
ef6f2287bae00ba79475fbf56c2b6fee (16:41): abeb4c0ac6ffb27ee5fbbc20aca0b2f4: Very little.
abeb4c0ac6ffb27ee5fbbc20aca0b2f4 (16:41): ef6f2287bae00ba79475fbf56c2b6fee: agreed.

ef6f2287bae00ba79475fbf56c2b6fee (16:43): abeb4c0ac6ffb27ee5fbbc20aca0b2f4: My point is that the effect on the user experience is what matters (or at least, what should matter), for anything other than syntactic sugar.
a924fb58d2c25874322f4e5126f608b9 (16:43): Is there a one-liner about "author education" similar to "the tools will save us"?
cc097e0d7183ae8436e7df709553c8c0 (16:44): Zeldman will save us

ef6f2287bae00ba79475fbf56c2b6fee (16:44): So if different elements for wrapping form controls have an effect on the user experience, I don't see why HTML5 shouldn't have conformance criteria about it.
a924fb58d2c25874322f4e5126f608b9 (16:44): (and "search engines can use it")

abeb4c0ac6ffb27ee5fbbc20aca0b2f4 (16:45): ef6f2287bae00ba79475fbf56c2b6fee: so you aren't distinguishing between features that extend the platform (canvas, video, etc.) and features that extend the language (header, footer, cite). I think it's unwise to treat all features as being in the same class. There are clearly differences between browser features (which, as you say, directly effect the UX) and language features (which affect semantics ...invisible but still important).
ef6f2287bae00ba79475fbf56c2b6fee (16:46): I think all semantic distinctions have a /potential/ effect on user agents.

abeb4c0ac6ffb27ee5fbbc20aca0b2f4 (16:46): ef6f2287bae00ba79475fbf56c2b6fee: I certainly don't equate semantics with "syntactic sugar." HTML is a markup, not a programming, language (or, now with HTML5) it is a markup *and* a programming language.
ef6f2287bae00ba79475fbf56c2b6fee (16:46): For example, screen readers offer keys for navigating list elements, tables, and "paragraphs" independently.
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (16:46): abeb4c0ac6ffb27ee5fbbc20aca0b2f4: header and footer should be considered to extend the platform, IMO
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (16:46): abeb4c0ac6ffb27ee5fbbc20aca0b2f4: as far as exposure to AT goes

abeb4c0ac6ffb27ee5fbbc20aca0b2f4 (16:48): hsivoven: help me think of a better example of "extending the language" i.e. new semantics that don't require undue work from browser makers in order for authors to use them.

ef6f2287bae00ba79475fbf56c2b6fee (16:48): abeb4c0ac6ffb27ee5fbbc20aca0b2f4: I don't equate semantics with syntactic sugar. But the important thing about semantic features (as opposed to mere naming conventions) is that user agents can /do/ things with those semantics.
a924fb58d2c25874322f4e5126f608b9 (16:48): Was I the only one laughing when Sam assumed wcag had peer review?
a924fb58d2c25874322f4e5126f608b9 (16:49): I wasn't even involved in the process, but I still remember all the blog posts about how it ignored input and feedback

abeb4c0ac6ffb27ee5fbbc20aca0b2f4 (16:50): ef6f2287bae00ba79475fbf56c2b6fee: even naming conventions *can* be used by user agents (see: microformats) so I don't think there's such a clear distinction between semantics and naming conventions. Both can be potentially used by user agents.
ef6f2287bae00ba79475fbf56c2b6fee (16:50): abeb4c0ac6ffb27ee5fbbc20aca0b2f4: (My point about syntactic sugar is that unlike other features, it's only of interest to authors.)

a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554 (16:51): Yes, yes, whatever you said Dr Graham

ef6f2287bae00ba79475fbf56c2b6fee (16:51): abeb4c0ac6ffb27ee5fbbc20aca0b2f4: That's true, and to the extent that user agents can do things with them, it's appropriate for them to specified (see: microformat specs).

abeb4c0ac6ffb27ee5fbbc20aca0b2f4 (16:51): ef6f2287bae00ba79475fbf56c2b6fee: I disagree. When enough authors agree on semantic usage, user agents can make use of that collective decision. Admittedly, this doesn't happen that often but it doesn't happen that often with regular elements either.
